awd_titl_txt: Supporting Teacher Practice to Facilitate and Assess Oral Scientific Argumentation: Embedding a Real-Time Assessment of Speaking and Listening into an Argumentation-Rich Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
This is an early-stage design and development collaborative study submitted to the assessment strand of the Discovery Research PreK-12 (DRK-12) program, in response to Program Solicitation NSF 15-592. The fundamental purpose of this project is to support teacher practice and professional learning around oral scientific argumentation in order to improve the quality of this practice in classrooms. To achieve this purpose, the project will examine the validity of a new technology-based formative assessment tool for classroom argumentation--"Diagnosing the Argumentation Levels of Groups" (DiALoG)--for which psychometric validation work has been conducted in a laboratory setting. The DiALoG assessment tool allows teachers to document classroom talk and display scores across multiple dimensions--both intrapersonal and interpersonal--for formative assessment purposes. The project will work with 6th-8th grade science teachers to monitor and support argumentation through real-time formative assessment data generated by the DiALoG instrument. DiALoG will be used in conjunction with "Amplify Science", a Lawrence Hall of Science-developed curriculum that incorporates the science practice of engaging in argument from evidence, and a suite of newly developed Responsive Mini-Lessons (RMLs), which consist of 20-30 minute instructional strategies designed to assist teachers to provide feedback to students' thinking and follow-up to argumentation episodes that the DiALoG tool identifies in need of further support. The study will allow the refinement and expansion of DiALoG and evaluation of its impact on teacher pedagogical content knowledge and formative assessment practices in widespread classroom use.

The project will address two specific research questions: (1) How can DiALoG be refined to provide a formative assessment tool for oral argumentation that is reliable, practical, and useful in middle school classrooms?; and (2) How does the use of DiALoG affect teacher formative assessment practices around evidence-based argumentation, when implementing science units designed to support oral argumentation? In order to answer these questions, the project will conduct a randomized control trial with 100 teachers: 50 will teach argumentation-focused curriculum with DiALoG, 50 will teach the same curriculum without DiALoG. Both control and treatment teachers will receive all digital and physical materials needed to teach three Amplify Science curriculum units. Treatment teachers will be provided also with the most recent version of DiALoG, including the linked RMLs, as well as support materials for using DiALoG with the Amplify curriculum. A subgroup of focus teachers (5 from the treatment group, and 5 from the control group) will be the subject of additional data collection and analysis. Three focus lessons, in which students are engaging in small-group or whole-class oral argumentation, will be selected from each of the three Amplify Science curricular units. Teacher measures for the randomized control trial will include validated instruments, such as (a) a pre- and post-assessment of teacher pedagogical content knowledge; (b) post-lesson and post-unit surveys in which teachers will self-report on their formative assessment practices; and (c) video recordings of selected lessons in the focus classrooms. In order to observe potential differences in formative assessment practices between treatment and control, protocols will be used to analyze the video recordings of focus classrooms, including (a) Reformed Teaching Observation Protocol; (b) Assessment of Scientific Argumentation inside the Classroom; and (c) Formative Assessment for Teachers and Students. The key outcome of this work will be a research-informed and field-tested prototype to improve the quality of teaching and learning argumentation in middle school science classrooms usable in different learning environments.

por.por_cntn:
The fundamental purpose of this project is to support teacher practice and professional learning around oral scientific argumentation in order to improve the quality of this practice in classrooms. To achieve this purpose, the project has refining for broad release and investigated the classroom uses of a new technology-based formative assessment tool for classroom argumentation. This assessment tool for "Diagnosing the Argumentation Levels of Groups" (DiALoG) allows teachers to document classroom talk and display scores across multiple aspects of scientific argumentation for formative assessment purposes. 

Our work has focused on finding out how we might support the teacher – and ultimately the students – in seeing, acknowledging and fostering student growth within the entire, complex interaction that is scientific argumentation. Our conceptualization of the relationship between the product and the process within scientific argumentation builds on Garcia-Mila and Andersen’s (2008) and Simon, Erduran and Osborne (2006), and others who aim to describe these two interrelated dimensions. In our work to develop a formative assessment schema, and ultimately tool, we call these dimensions the intrapersonal and the interpersonal. We conceive of the intrapersonal components of argumentation as the components of an argument that students learn in order to become more fluent in the discourse of argumentation – the components that an individual student conceives of internally while considering an argument – while interpersonal components of argumentation are those that students learn in order to communicate effectively with each other about the arguments they want to make and then utilize them in conjunction with others  (e.g., to persuade or to co-construct). In developing the DiALoG sytem, we integrated this notion of intra- and inter-personal dimensions of scientific argumentation within the framework of Accountable Talk (Michaels, O’Connor, & Resnick, 2008; Michaels, O’Connor, Williams-Hall, Resnick, 2010), which seeks to transform classrooms from places where students respond only to the teacher, to provide accurate, recalled facts, to places where students ‘...grapple with complicated, questions, puzzle through new kinds of problems and interpret complex texts,” (Resnick, Asterhan & Clarke, 2018). Accountable Talk thereby provides a pathway for teaching students how to run sophisticated, structured, independent conversations.

To investigate DiALoG, the project worked with 6th-8th grade science teachers across the United States to monitor and support argumentation through real-time formative assessment data generated by the DiALoG tool. Researchers investigated teachers’ use of the DiALoG tool in conjunction with a suite of newly developed Responsive Mini-Lessons (RMLs), which consist of 20-30 minute instructional strategies designed to assist teachers to provide feedback to students' thinking and follow-up to argumentation episodes that the DiALoG tool identifies in need of further support. For the study, teachers used the DiALoG tool and RML system with middle school science units from "Amplify Science", a Lawrence Hall of Science-developed curriculum that incorporates the science practice of engaging in argument from evidence. The study enabled multiple iterations of the DiALoG system to be grounded in evidence from the classroom and provided a rigorous test of the system’s impact on teacher pedagogical content knowledge and formative assessment practices in widespread classroom use.
Through our iterative, design-based research process, we learned that the DiALoG system provides students and teachers with supports for guiding students into becoming members of a science discourse community, where all members are accountable to science facts and logical ways of interpreting those facts. The Intrapersonal components of the DiALoG system provide clear ways for classroom teachers and students to understand claims, evidence, reasoning and relevance as they relate to the fluid, ever-changing argumentation that occurs in classroom discussions  In conjunction with supporting classroom learning in-the-moment, DiALoG was conceived of as a tool to support teacher noticing. Building on Goodwin’s (1994) notion of professional vision, Sherin and van Es (2003; 2009) introduced the concept of teacher noticing as a way of conceptualizing how teachers employ professional knowledge as they provide instruction and support for students. Thus, as the teacher uses the DiALoG scoring rubric, she is guided to observe and make sense of the complicated, lightning-fast maelstrom of student discourse that can happen when students are working to make sense of ideas. The Inter- and Intrapersonal categories are available to support the teacher in noticing specific aspects of oral argumentation – both the ‘pieces’ of an argument – claims, evidence reasoning and relevance – and the behaviors that occur between students during a discussion – listening, co-constructing, critiquing and regulation. In particular, we observed how the scoring rubric supports teachers in noticing the latter components associated with student behaviors. Ultimately, DiALoG provides a way for teachers to notice more about their students' developing argumentation practice, and gives them a richer vision of oral argumentation, upon which they are able to both develop their own, more complete vision of oral argumentation and guide their students to see it more completely as well.
